newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - June 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - June 20.

text.p: The following are the highlights of stories from the Irish press on Friday.
- Tax cuts pledge is centrepiece of programme for Ireland's new government
- British retailing giant Safeway, is to set up a chain of about 20 superstores in the Republic's main urban locations
- Fitzwilton and Safeway plan to spend 250 million punts on chain of stores
- Cabinet approves a telemarketing project by Consolidated Financial Insurance, a subsidiary of GE Capital Services, in Shannon which would create over 500 jobs
- Pretax profits at Telecom Eireann rise by 76 percent to 204 million punts
- James Crean sells its American office products company Master Products to Martin Yales Industries
- A senior Revenue official was arrested as a major investigation into an alleged multi-million pound tax scam was stepped up
- Government partners pledge autumn tax cuts
- Musgrave posts 7.6 million increase in pretax profits to 25.56 million for 1996
- Buoyant Telecom facing large dividend pay-out
- Fitzwilton sells stores but has 50 percent stake in Safeway joint venture
- Fianna Fail/Progressive Democrats sign up for power - American group to invest 20 million punts in Shannon and create 530 jobs
- Hewlett Packard to create 1,000 jobs in Leixlip
